name: Thessaloniki
fun_fact: Fun fact: Thessaloniki is Greece's foodie capital and UNESCO City of Gastronomy - locals say the food here is better than Athens because of Turkish, Balkan, and Jewish influences from the 1922 population exchange.

hero_dishes.name: Bougatsa
hero_dishes.description: Flaky phyllo pastry filled with sweet semolina custard, topped with powdered sugar and cinnamon, or savory with cheese/meat
hero_dishes.origin_story: Bougatsa came from Byzantine times but exploded after the 1922 population exchange when Greeks from Asia Minor brought the recipe. Thessaloniki has over 1,000 bougatsa-selling spots - it's the breakfast of champions. The traditional sweet custard version is iconic, but cheese, meat, and even chocolate versions exist now.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bougatsa Giannis (136 Mitropoleos Street), Mpantis (city's most delicious bougatsa for decades), Serraikon (reputation for best in Thessaloniki), Estrella (famous bougatsan - baked croissant with custard and seasonal fruits)

hero_dishes.name: Pita Gyro Sandwich
hero_dishes.description: Pork or chicken gyro meat from vertical rotisserie, wrapped in pita with fries, tomatoes, onions, and spicy cheese sauce (tirokafteri)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Thessaloniki's gyro is famously larger than Athens' souvlaki. The pita works extra hard to wrap around all the ingredients. Instead of classic tzatziki, Northern Greeks prefer spicy cheese sauce (tirokafteri). The meat-to-bread-to-fries ratio is an art form perfected over generations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street food vendors throughout the city - locals know gyros is served traditional way with fries and onions in pita, only souvlaki goes with tzatziki

hero_dishes.name: Pulpo a la Gallega (Grilled Octopus)
hero_dishes.description: Fresh octopus grilled to tender perfection with olive oil and lemon, or as part of meze spreads
hero_dishes.origin_story: As a harbor city, Thessaloniki's seafood is legendary. The octopus here is 'truly in a league of its own.' Grilled simply to let freshness shine, or served as part of meze spreads. The Kalamaria district specializes in upscale seafood with especially tasty grilled octopus.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Ouzeri Aristotelous (charming waterfront taverna with freshest seafood), Kalamaria seaside district (upscale seafood restaurants and trendy cafes), Ladadika district tavernas

hero_dishes.name: Meze Spreads
hero_dishes.description: Multiple small plates - tzatziki, taramosalata, melitzanosalata (eggplant), fava, grilled octopus, mussels, fried calamari
hero_dishes.origin_story: Meze culture in Thessaloniki reflects multicultural heritage - Turkish mezze tradition meets Greek seafood and Balkan flavors. Sharing many small plates with wine or ouzo is how Thessalonians socialize. It's not a meal, it's an event lasting hours.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Ladadika district (Morichovou Square, Katouni or Vaiou streets - traditional tavernas), Bit Bazaar (small square filled with family-run restaurants), waterfront tavernas

signature_drinks.name: Ouzo
signature_drinks.description: Anise-flavored Greek spirit that turns milky white when mixed with water
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served with meze - never drunk without food. Mixed with water and ice, sipped slowly while grazing on small plates. The ritual of sharing meze and ouzo can last all afternoon. Ouzeri (ouzo bars) are social institutions.

signature_drinks.name: Local Wine
signature_drinks.description: Northern Greek wines from Naoussa and nearby regions - robust reds and crisp whites
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with meze and seafood. Northern Greece produces excellent wines that pair perfectly with rich meze spreads. Locals drink it throughout meals, taking time to enjoy food and conversation.
